title: Introduction to Archaeology
description: An introduction to the working assumptions, analytic approaches, and integrative and descriptive methods of archaeological anthropology.

title: An Introduction to Classical Studies
description: An introduction to Greek and Roman civilization, focusing on six key aspects of the discipline of classical studies: history, literature, philosophy, myth and religion, art and architecture, and classical archaeology.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: No more than 0.50 unit in CLAS

title: Love, Life, and Death in Greece
description: This course surveys how different people gave meaning to their lives in ancient Greece. It will cover topics ranging from personal identities, culture wars, sports, art, myth, and history, to sex, slavery, and social justice.

title: Greek History
description: A survey of ancient Greek history, from the Bronze Age to Alexander the Great, emphasizing particularly its political and military aspects.

title: Greek and Roman Religion
description: An examination of the religious beliefs and cult practices of the classical world. Topics include prayer and sacrifice; divination and oracles; temples, priests, and festivals; mystery cults and their relation to Christianity.  [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1 requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

title: Survey of Greek Art and Architecture
description: A survey of Greek art and architecture from the earliest times to the coming of the Romans. Material studied may include the art of the Bronze Age, the development of Greek sculpture, the evolution of the Acropolis at Athens, and the change in art and architecture after Alexander the Great.

title: History of Ancient Law
description: A historical introduction to law in the ancient world. Babylonian, Assyrian, Hittite, and Roman law, legal practices, and concepts will be examined.

title: The Ancient Near East and Egypt
description: A study of the civilizations of the ancient Near East focusing on Mesopotamia (Sumer and Akkad, the Babylonian Dynasty, and the Third Dynasty of Ur), Hatti, Assyria, Egypt, and Persia.

title: History of Ancient Philosophy
description: In this course students will examine one or more important figures, periods, or issues in ancient philosophy. Plato and Aristotle are among the philosophers who may be covered. [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

title: Senior Seminar
description: Each fall and winter term a senior seminar on some aspect of Greek or Roman civilization will be offered. [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]
requirementsDescription: Prereq: CLAS 251, 252; CLAS 231 or 232; CLAS 241 or 242

title: Classical Mythology
description: A study of Greco-Roman mythology and legend, with special emphasis on the Olympian gods and the figure of the hero. Topics may include myths of creation, the rise of the gods, divine myths, the tales surrounding the cities of Troy, Mycenae, and Thebes and the heroes Herakles, Perseus, and Theseus.

title: Research Methods in Classical Studies
description: A team-taught course exploring the variety of methodologies involved in studying the ancient Mediterranean, with a focus on Greco-Roman civilization and its transmission to us.  Each contributing faculty member will showcase the particular methodologies employed in his or her research.  This course is taught int he Fall term and is a required course for all MA students.

title: Studies in Ancient Art and Architecture
description: An investigation of selected themes, topics, time periods, artistic media or styles in ancient art and architecture.  This course is repeatable provided that the topic is different.  One example could be The Sacred Island of Delos: Cultural Crossroads.
